answers: Studs Terkel [or Louis Terkel]
oral history
Soviet Invasion of Afghanistan [or Soviet-Afghan War; prompt on the Cold War]
parts: Identify this historian and Chicago-area radio host behind books like Working and The Good War.

Terkel's Working is this type of history, which collects verbatim interviews from people and presents them directly in the text. This type of history has been widely adopted by websites to revisit pop culture events.

Another prominent oral historian, Svetlana Alexievich, interviewed participants in this conflict for her book Boys in Zinc. The US boycotted the 1980 Summer Olympics in opposition to one side in this war.

answers: sweat [or sweating; prompt on perspiration or perspirant]
chloride [or Cl-; do not accept or prompt on chlorine]
capsaicin
parts: Identify this fluid which is released in order to control body temperature. It can accumulate on the forehead or under the armpits during stressful situations.
One way to diagnose cystic fibrosis is to measure for elevated amounts of this ion in one's sweat because the defective CFTR channels impair the reabsorption of this ion and sodium.

The binding of this chemical compound to TRPV1 receptors leads to gustatory sweating as a thermoregulatory response. Like lidocaine, a patch containing this compound may be used to control peripheral neuropathy.

answers: Hopscotch [or Rayuela]
Julio Cortázar [or Julio Florencio Cortázar]
Mario Vargas Llosa [or Jorge Mario Pedro Vargas Llosa, 1st Marquess of Vargas Llosa; prompt on Llosa]
parts: Name this stream-of-consciousness novel that follows characters such as Talita and Horatio Oliveira, the latter of whom is searching for La Maga. It has 99 expendable chapters.
Hopscotch was written by this Argentine author of the story "The Axolotl."

According to scholarly consensus, the Latin American Boom of the 1960s and 70s either began with the publication of Hopscotch or with this author's novel The Time of the Hero. This Peruvian right-winger wrote Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter.

answers: bluestockings [or Bluestocking Society; or Bluestocking Circle]
salons [accept cabinet or réduit or ruelle or alcôve]
Jacques Necker
parts: Identify this now-derisive term for a group of intellectual women such as Hester Thrale and Elizabeth Montagu.
Montagu hosted one of these intellectual gatherings. Girondins discussed politics at one of these regular gatherings hosted at the home of Madame Roland.

One influential salon was hosted by the wife of this Swiss-born Minister of Finance to Louis XVI (16), whose widely-read 1781 report on the French budget grossly oversold the country's fiscal solvency.

answers: labor force participation rate [or LFPR; or economic activity rate; do not accept "unemployment rate"]
capital [accept human capital or Das Kapital]
pink [accept pink tax or pink-collar jobs]
parts: Name this stat, the total number of people in the workforce or looking for work divided by the total number of potential workers.
Goldin argued that the "high school movement" in the US led to a century of increasing the "human" form of this factor of production that also titles a Karl Marx book.

Goldin has also written about women's over-representation in low-paying, caregiving jobs described by this adjective. A "tax" named for this adjective refers to the extra price attached to products marketed to women.

answers: cosmic dust [or space dust; accept intergalactic, interstellar, or interplanetary dust; prompt on interstellar medium or ISM]
ecliptic plane [prompt on answers indicating the rotational plane of Earth or the rotational plane of the planets]
Spitzer Space Telescope [accept Spitzer Warm Mission; prompt on Space Infrared Telescope Facility or SIRTF]
parts: Name this substance whose many fine particles absorb and scatter visible light.
Within our solar system, dust produces a dim light over the horizon along this plane, which defines the zodiac constellations. This plane is inclined 23.4 degrees from the axis of the Earth.

This telescope can probe objects surrounded by dense dust because IR light can penetrate through. This telescope trails Earth in a heliocentric orbit to avoid accidentally heating up, and it entered its productive "warm" period after running out of coolant.

answers: soul [accept "Body and Soul"; accept "Heart and Soul"]
Charlie Parker Jr.
"Send in the Clowns"
parts: Vaughan was discovered at the Apollo singing a song titled for the "Body" and this other entity. Hoagy Carmichael and Frank Loesser wrote a famous standard titled for "Heart" and this entity.
Vaughan helped pioneer bebop as part of the Earl Hines Big Band, which included this bebop saxophonist who was nicknamed “Bird.” This musician wrote standards such as “Ornithology” and “Ko-Ko.”
Vaughan sang a three-octave version of this song, which opens "Isn't it rich? / Are we a pair?". This song, a signature of Judy Collins, comes from Act II of Stephen Sondheim's A Little Night Music.

answers: Zadie Smith [or Sadie Smith]
Granta
Nobel Prize in Literature [prompt on Nobel Prize]
parts: Name this author who wrote about Samad Iqbal and Archie Jones in her novel White Teeth.

"Just Right" was published in a 2013 issue of this literary magazine that publishes a list of the best young British novelists every decade. It has published essays by authors of color about "How to Write About Africa" and "How to Write About Pakistan."
Olga Tokarczuk, who has been published by Granta, won this prize in 2018 for her novel Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead. Poet Louise Glück won this prize in 2020.

answers: lead [or Pb]

hole in the ozone layer [or Antarctic hole in the ozone layer; the depletion of the ozone layer; or thinning of the ozone layer; prompt on air pollution; prompt on air quality; prompt on climate change on the grounds that fixing the ozone layer helps reduce climate change; prompt on just ozone layer] (the invention was freon)
paint [or lacquer; or automotive paint; or mineral paint; prompt on pigments]
parts: While at General Motors, Kettering came up with adding this toxic substance to gasoline. Pipes made from this element may have contributed to the fall of the Roman Empire.
Another Kettering invention contributed to this problem, which was addressed after Kettering's death by the 1987 Montreal Protocol.
More positively, Kettering invented a form of this stuff called Duco for the DuPont company. In fiction, Silas Lapham makes his fortune manufacturing this stuff.

answers: Brueghel [accept Jan Brueghel the Elder]
Ghent Altarpiece [accept Adoration of the Mystic Lamb]
Hieronymous Bosch [or Jheronimus Bosch or Joen Bosch or Joen van Aken or Jheronimus van Aken]
parts: An artist from this family painted animals and flowers for The Garden of Eden with the Fall of Man, in which his collaborator Peter Paul Rubens painted Adam and Eve. That same artist from this family also worked with Rubens on The Five Senses.

Adam and Eve flank two angels playing instruments and face towards the center from the extremes of this work. Many groups of people admiringly gather around a lamb bleeding into a grail in another section of this work.
God grabs Eve's wrist as Adam wakes up and watches in the left panel of this artist's triptych The Garden of Earthly Delights.

answers: Fǎlún Gōng [or Fǎlún Dàfǎ]
The Epoch Times [accept Epoch Media Group]
aliens [or extraterrestrials; accept obvious synonyms]
parts: Name this Chinese religion founded by Lǐ Hóngzhì, which includes breathing exercises called qìgōng (“chee-gong”). It also operates the Shen Yun performance troupe.

A 2021 Atlantic article describes how employees of this Fǎlún Gōng-operated, anti-communist media outlet were encouraged to spend 15 minutes every six hours to close their eyes and "send forth righteous thoughts."
Lǐ Hóngzhì claimed that these beings introduced modern technology to control humans. According to Scientology, one of these beings named Xenu formerly ruled the Earth.

answers: Wales [prompt on United Kingdom or Great Britain; do not accept or prompt on "England"]
a cauldron [prompt on pot or kettle]
salmon [accept salmon of knowledge]
parts: Name this country whose myths, including a prose narrative made up of four "branches," were translated into English by Lady Charlotte Guest.

The Welsh poet Taliesin (“ta-lee-ESH-in”) tended one of these objects for a year as a servant for Ceridwen (“CARE-id-wen”). In another myth, Efnisien (“eff-NISH-en”) destroys one of these objects that can revive the dead.
The myth about Taliesin and the Cauldron of Inspiration is similar to the tale of Finn MacCool, who gains wisdom from eating a drop of the fat of one of these fish.

answers: Boston, Massachusetts [accept Boston Brahmins]
Lowell family [accept Robert Lowell; accept James Russell Lowell]
Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr.
parts: "Elite" northeastern families like the Cabots and Thayers are referred to as this city's "Brahmins." Part 2 of The Sound and the Fury opens at Harvard in this city's suburb of Cambridge.

One member of this "Brahmin" literary family wrote the Confessional poetry collection Life-Studies. An earlier member of this family said that Edgar Allan Poe was "two-fifths genius, three-fifths sheer fudge" in A Fable for Critics.
This physician coined "anesthesia" and "Boston Brahmin." He also wrote "The Deacon's Masterpiece."

answers: Tuareg [or Twareg; Touareg]
Ibn Khaldun [or Abū Zayd 'Abd ar-Raḥmān ibn Muḥammad ibn Khaldūn al-Ḥaḍramī; prompt on Khaldun]
Senegal [or Republic of Senegal; accept Senegal River]
parts: Identify these people whose Kel Owey clan controlled much of northern Niger in the 19th century. Timbuktu was captured in a rebellion named for these Berber people that broke out in 2012.
Berber peoples like the Tuareg constructed mausoleums called jedars. Some early evidence of the jedars comes from the Prolegomena of this well-traveled Tunisian historian of the 14th century.
Tuareg camel caravans often carried gold mined along a river of this name, which shares its name with a modern-day country with a capital at Dakar.

answers: protons
Lamb shift
magnetic field [or B field]
parts: Identify this particle. The number of these particles in the nucleus of an atom determines an element's atomic number.
Hessels' team used this energy difference to measure the proton's radius. This contributor to the fine structure is the energy difference between the 2S and 2P states in the hydrogen atom.
Another contributor to the fine structure is the Zeeman effect, which is a splitting of spectral lines in the presence of one of these entities.

answers: China [or People's Republic of China; or PRC] [or (The second composer is Tan Dun.)
India [or Republic of India]
percussion instruments [accept drums, gongs, or other specific percussion instruments]
parts: Young was inspired by the sounds of telephone poles for one of a set of four "dreams" of this country. A composer from this country incorporates instruments made of paper, stones, and water into his pieces, such as Water Concerto.
Young studied under a musician from this country, Pandit Pran Nath, whose droning tanpura music inspired Young's later music. Sitars are used in this country's music.
Young drew inspiration from Chatur Lal, a tabla player. The tabla is an instrument from this family, which contains most instruments that make up the gamelan ensemble.

answers: Gerhart Hauptmann
fairies [accept sprites] (the Shakespeare play is A Midsummer Night's Dream)
Bertolt Brecht [or Eugen Berthold Friedrich Brecht]
parts: Name this German dramatist who wrote about a riot led by Moritz Jaeger against the harsh policies of Dreissiger in his play The Weavers.

In Hauptmann's play The Sunken Bell, Heinrich completes a bell which is to be hung on a mountain inhabited by these characters. Mob and Cobweb are two of these beings in a Shakespeare comedy set in Athens.
An unrelated author named Elisabeth Hauptmann may have worked with this author on his "play with music" The Threepenny Opera. He also wrote Mother Courage and Her Children.

answers: eucalyptus trees [or eucalypti; or gum trees; or stringybark trees; prompt on Myrtaceae]

Voltammetry analyzes this class of reaction in which electrons are transferred between molecules in two half-reactions.
